Approximately 400 seniors in the Albany Career and Technical School campuses were honored during morning and afternoon awards ceremonies. Most of the students – typically more than 70 percent – will pursue college or technical school; others will go directly into the workforce into high-paying jobs they were recruited for while at BOCES.

Dozens of awards ranging from college scholarships to program awards were handed out during the event. Below is the list of RCS scholarship recipients. Congratulations to the RCS District students receiving their scholarships!

The Springwater Bistro Culinary Award - Taylor Lange, Culinary Arts Tech Prep.

The Red Cross Scholarship - Justin Firstiun, Patient Care Assistant/Home Health Aide.

Everyone’s journey to graduation takes a pathway. Meet RCS Senior J.D. Bagley. From having a disinterest in school to becoming an honor-roll student with a full-time job even before he graduates. He was hired earlier this year by Capital Region BOCES business partner DePaula’s Auto Group in Albany while still completing his education at BOCES. “I started working at DePaula’s in January and I work there 30 to 40 hours a week,” Bagley said. “I will work full-time for them when I graduate.”

The path to full-time employment at a major automotive dealer was filled with obstacles for Bagley. Bagley said he owes the turnaround to being engaged in his learning and to getting support from BOCES faculty members.

Bagley is one of about 100 students enrolled in the automotive program on the Albany and Schoharie campuses. The two-year program covers engine theory and specialized tools and equipment to customer service and shop management. Congrats to you J.D. and all of our graduates!

Meet Dominic Notaro. At the age of three, he was diagnosed with Autism. During the early years of his diagnosis, his family sought out the right program and support network for him. With guidance from the RCS District he was able to find a solution that best fit his needs. He was originally told that his educational goal would be a CDOS credential, which is recognized by the NYS Board of Regents as a certificate that states that a student has the knowledge and ability necessary for entry level employment.

That wouldn’t be enough for Dominic. He wanted a high school diploma, just like his older brothers. To learn more about his journey and his path to graduation, go to bit.ly/3dMWROF.

A dozen high school students are well on their way to becoming Emergency Medical Technicians after completing a Capital Region BOCES program. The seniors in the New Visions: Health Careers program recently passed the New York State Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) practical exam - showing they understand the protocols and have the skills to function as EMTs. They now must pass the written exam, which will be offered at some future date when the state allows for mass testing in the Albany area, to become EMTs and practice in New York State.

The longstanding New Visions: Health Careers is designed for high school seniors interested in medical and health-related professions. Students learn through traditional methods as well as rotations in various hospital departments. Those rotations are structured observations of professionals and procedures in a career field.

A special congratulations goes to RCS senior Hannah Call for passing the practical exam. Best of luck as you prepare to serve your community as an EMT.

Recently, a number of students in the Capital Region BOCES Career and Technical School Cosmetology Program completed training that would give them an upper hand in seeking employment by showing that they have professional knowledge of infection control practices. During this time, infection control has played a greater role, including salons and hair studios, as they prepare to reopen their businesses. The health and safety of their customers is always a priority.

The two-hour certification shows that students understand at a professional level how to create a “prevention environment” on the building and salon levels, how to develop standards, how to ensure their tools and equipment are safe, occupational health risks, contagious diseases and transmission and personal protection. Special recognition goes to RCS student Adrianna Grant for completing this important certification. A great step towards being a professional in the workplace, while building her portfolio for future employers.

We complete our outreach for Teacher Appreciation Week with one final thank you. As many know, Mrs. Stott has been an educator in the RCS school district for over 30 years. She has been a positive role model for students seeking to better themselves. She credits entering her profession to assist young people with achieving their potential, and loved helping them on their respective journey.

She will officially retire from teaching in June. But, she wanted to share one quote with the RCS community, and especially her students, past and present:

“My message to my students has been displayed on my classroom walls since I began teaching more than 30 years ago - “You are the author of your own life story.” Life is all about choices.”

We thank you, Mrs. Stott.

A community is only as strong as its members. In the RCS district, we have an amazing story of an RCS staff member and her effort to protect health care workers. Meet Linda O'Brien. Mrs. O'Brien is a Teaching Assistant at the RCS Middle School. During this time, she has been working with regional and statewide health care workers to ensure their safety, while they do their job to help others. She's currently designing and creating surgical covers for N95 respirators that are being used by doctors and nurses in hospitals. Her masks are used as a protective cover for the N95 respirator, which allow them to be used longer by those health care professionals.

She has been providing these masks for the past few weeks and continues to give assistance to those in need. She's making a difference. No matter the impact, being kind and thoughtful to others is important. As a community, we can help those in need. Thank you, Mrs. O'Brien.

You are loved."

We appreciate Mr. Gray for taking the time to share his story and interact with our students. Thank you.

A number of fourth grade students from Pieter B. Coeymans Elementary School received a tour of the Times Union. Currently, the students are busy at work on their school-based newspaper: Keeping Up with the Bees. As part of the research and preparation for that publication, students were invited to visit the newspaper and met with Times Union Advertising Director Greg Stapleton. During the tour, Mr. Stapleton provided them with an inside view of the printing process and how a newspaper is compiled for our region.

Numerous topics were discussed, such as: daily reporting, planning, layout and printing of an actual newspaper. The class also received a historical lesson on the importance of newspapers and the critical role they play in our society. The Keeping Up with the Bees newspaper exercise is led by RCS Project Based Learning Coach Kate Thibault.

Stay tuned for updates on their progress and see how they are sharing news and information with their fellow classmates!

As winter rolls along, the RCS Middle School Physical Education department has added a new sport to keep students active and fit, while beating those winter blues! The new sport, known as Pickleball, is being recognized as one of the fastest growing sports in the United States. The activity encompasses elements of tennis, badminton and table tennis. Teams are usually between two and four players and requires the use of solid wooden paddles and a perforated polymer ball, similar to a Whiffle Ball, played over a low-slung net.

“This activity allows students to have fun, while fine tuning their motor skills,” said RCS Middle School Physical Education teacher Megan McClave. “It’s a fast growing activity and provides a lifetime fitness option for people of all ages. The students love playing and it’s a great addition to the RCS Physical Education department curriculum.”

If your child or friend is talking about Pickleball take notice. It creates great energy and can help beat the winter blues, while keeping you sharp and having fun. Pick up a paddle and find out if it’s for you!

Such an interesting program that continues to deliver opportunities for RCS students.

Here’s what she had to say: “Not only am I a graduate of RCS, but I have two boys that will graduate from our district along with other family members. I have a vested interest in the success of our school district. I want to see all students become successful adults and community members.”
